title: huge-asset-borders-closed
story: THE Girl Guide movement in Scotland has been left ldquoheartbroken after it was announced this week that its Borders-based activity centre would shut for good.The closure of Netherurd House near Blyth Bridge is said to be due to financial dficulty, with the impact of the coronavirus pandemic being the final nail in the coffin.Staff will be made redundant, with the exception of the groundskeeper who will be retained until the estate is sold.Margot Swanston, who has visited Netherurd for  years as a guide and leader, described herself as ldquodevastated.The stunning Georgian mansion and its extensive grounds have served thousands of guides and brownies for more than  years.After finances plummeted five years ago, a review was carried out which resulted in signicant investment to improve facilities and make it more attractive for users.There was an initial increase in bookings, but over the last three years numbers dropped, resulting in fewer users and financial woes.Girlguiding Scotlandrsquos chief commissioner Moira McKenna said: ldquoIn the past, we regularly used to fill the house with adults for county and other training weekends, but this has been declining for at least the last decade.ldquoFewer counties book for training, more of them come for only one night and the numbers from each county are lower than in previous times.ldquoThere is now much more training available online and this has increased dramatically this year with COVID-.ldquoEven before the pandemic came along, Girlguiding was planning to set up a digital hub to provide training online, and whilst we know the value of being together, volunteers across Scotland are finding the online or local training options more convenient in terms of both time and money.ldquoWe had hoped to build external business for mid-week, especially schools, but we were unable to build a wide enough business base to rely on this.ldquoEach year we have tried other avenues including holidays for Trefoil groups, retreats for local churches, private family gatherings and occasional weddings, but overall we could not generate enough routine business to help us improve the finances.ldquoThis was the situation before we were forced to close Netherurd in March due to COVID-, and since then the centre has had no income.A spokesperson for Netherurd House added: ldquoWe want to take this opportunity to say a huge thank you to all the staff and volunteers who have made Netherurd a place of adventure and provided ever-lasting memories for so many girls and young people.ldquoThis is a signicant loss to Girlguiding Scotland and we know many will be upset by this news.ldquoOur priority remains our members and wersquore committed to ensuring that girls and young women can keep having adventure and benefit from all that the outdoors has to offer.Former visitors to Netherurd House took to social media calling the closure a ldquosad day for Girlguiding Scotland.,params: .pushOne woman wrote: ldquoDreadful news. Broken-hearted doesnrsquot begin to describe the way Irsquom feeling. Netherurd has always been a home away from home to me.Joyce Sundstrem added: ldquoSuch sad news, an integral part of our Guiding over the years. Happy memories of training weekends and pack holidays there.ldquoItrsquos a shame to think the future rainbows, brownies and guides wonrsquot have the same chance to visit as we had.Many leaders and former users have described the news as a ldquodevastating tragedy for guiding and have even called for a rescue mission.Ms Swanston, the guidesrsquo assistant commissioner for Peebles, said: ldquoWe all hope it can be saved. I, as a guider, am devastated."I was  years old on my first guide camp and since then have stayed in the old Brownie house, the new Brownie house, and the big house itself.ldquoIt is not only a huge asset to Peeblesshire and the Borders, but to the whole of Scotland as it is the only residential venue owned by Girlguiding in Scotland.Ms Swanston and her family have strong ties in the Guiding movement and she says they have many happy memories of their time spent at Netherurd House.One cherished memory was formed only last October, when Ms Swanston renewed her Guide Promise after  years in Guiding.She added: ldquoMy granddaughter Megan took her Guide Promise for the first time and we were honoured by being enrolled by the Scottish Chief Guide.

title: castle-near-borders-now-tartan
story: A CASTLE near the Borders has ordered a new tartan to be created as part of its major refurbishment.Colin Frame, , began working to bring Biggars Shieldhill Castle back to le in January after growing up around the old fortress and hosting his wedding there in .After the castle fell into disrepair, Mr Frame saw its potential as a "bespoke wedding venue", giving couples the opportunity to "take over the whole place"."I grew up in the area near the castle," Mr Frame said. "When it was repossessed , it was empty for two years."I walked in and thought it had gone downhill. The property has a lot of neglect."Mr Frame, with his team of friends and local workers, has already managed to refurbish and decorate the ground floor of the hotel, which is due to open in September.The majority of rooms have been decorated, and remaining rooms will be completed by .As part of bringing the castle back to le, Shieldhill Castle has enlisted the help of world-renowned designers, Calzeat, of Biggar, to create a unique tartan to be used across the hotel in upholstery."Weve got a rich history of Scottish history here," said Mr Frame."The ability to customise our own pattern, not to be recreated by anyone , was really important."Calzeat director Bob Galbraith was excited to work with Shieldhill on the tartan project.He said: "I feel that it is very important to collaborate on this new and exciting project with a beautul local hotel."Apart from the very important relationship between the hotel and our mill, it gives the local community a chance to see our product in situ on their doorstep."The colours and layout of the tartan turned out just as we had hoped and definitely emulates the colours of the beautul, local countryside, as well as incorporating the corporate colours of the Shieldhill."Itrsquos a classic combination."The creation of the hotels tartan, as well as its rebuilding work, were completed during lockdown.But Mr Frame was pleased to tell this newspaper that although working during lockdown has been "hugely challenging across the UK", his team has still been able to operate under the restrictions.He explained: "We wouldnt have been open now anyway ."Weve managed to work around the restrictions and undertake the refurbishments ourselves."Mr Galbraith added: "Itrsquos been extremely dficult running a business during lockdown and wersquove to adapt in ious ways to survive through these dficult times."The new collaboration with the Shieldhill has been very rewarding in more ways than one."

title: school-opens-jedburgh-grammar-campus-welcomes-pupils
story: JEDBURGH Grammar Campus welcomed pupils to its pound million site this week.The new campus had been due to open in April, but the coronavirus pandemic forced plans to change.Yet on Wednesday , some pupils were able to enjoy their new classrooms at last, with the rest following yesterday .Jedburgh Grammar Campus head teacher Susan Oliver said staff were ldquodelighted to welcome pupils through the door, adding: ldquoWersquore in no doubt itrsquos been worth the wait."On Wednesday, the school welcomed nursery children, as well as pupils from primary one, S and S. All other pupils attended on Thursday.Other Borders schools reopened on Tuesday .The new Jedburgh site was built as part of the Schools for the Future programme launched by Deputy First Minister John Swinney in .The campus, which is open to pupils aged two to , replaces Jedburgh Grammar School and Parkside and Howdenburn primary schools.It boasts a G hockey pitch, a G sports pitch and a rural skills area.Parts of the building will allow public access, which will be monitored by Live Borders.The local charity will run sports and leisure facilities at the school, which are currently only available for outdoor activities in line with COVID- restrictions.Eventually, the public will also be allowed to use the campus for indoor activities, with library visits permitted too.Scottish Borders Councilleader Shona Haslam said: "Jedburgh Grammar Campus is a fantastic asset, with the equipment and facilities on offer providing a first-class learning environment for young people."I must thank all families in the Jedburgh area for their understanding and patience during this extremely challenging period."Mrs Haslam added: "We realise there will be some anxiety amongst pupils and parents carers arriving at the new campus, particularly in the current circumstances."However, I can assure them our first priority is the safety of pupils and staff, with a number of new COVID--related arrangements and routines in place.ldquoI also know our campus staff have worked extremely hard to help children settle into their exciting new learning space."Although Jedburgh Grammar Campus opened for pupil access on Thursday, an official opening of the site will be arranged when coronavirus guidelines are reduced to permit larger gatherings.Councillor Carol Hamilton, SBCrsquos executive member for children and young people, said: "Jedburgh Grammar Campus will provide signicant educational and wellbeing benefits for children, young people, families and the wider community in one location."For more information on the Jedburgh Grammar Campus, including FAQs, a video tour of the campus and guide on how to book leisure activities on-site with Live Borders, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk jedburghcampus

title: property-patter-make-home-feel-bigger-simple-tricks
story: During lockdown, many homes have had todouble up as offices, schools and even play areas.Although this may have been a temporary measure, you might find that you need some extra, permanent, space in your existing house.With some imagination and a surprisingly small budget, yoursquoll be amazed at what you can achieve without having to up sticks and move.StorageDo you have the room space but just too much stuff  For starters, it sounds obvious, but do a big clear out. With recycling centres and charity shops open again therersquos no excuse. Spend the weekend sorting through any unwanted items and donate where you can.For storage solutions, you need to think outside the box ndash literally. Vacuum bags are ideal, they normally come in multipacks of ious sizes and are really cheap. Great for anything soft that is taking up a lot of space. Winter clothes, quilts and blankets can be reduced to a tenth of the size and slide under the bed nicely.If floor space is a problem, then the sky is the limit. Consider storing items that arenrsquot needed on a regular basis above units or wardrobes. Think about shelving units that are tall and slim, rather than long and bulky.Cheap and cheerful plastic, canvas or cardboard boxes can help to keep everything in place while adding a splash of colour and style. Perfect for keeping clutter off the floor.Shelves above radiators are a great way to use otherwise wasted space.If the kids are desperate for some space, a reading nook or kids study area can easily be achieved under the stairs or a window. A simple storage box with a couple of cushions on top will create a comfy seat and can double up as extra storage.Hooks can be attached to pretty much anything like bedroom doors and inside cupboards ndash again keeping items off the floor will create the illusion of more space. In the kitchen, using hooks to hang pots and pans and magnets for knives can free up cupboard space and make a statement.Knowing where things are is half the battle when considering storage options, so think about clear plastic boxes or bags that are easy to see into and can be labelled.Flexible furniture like extendable dining tables, sofa beds and even clothes rails are ideal as they have multiple uses and can be stored away easily when not in use.Let there be lightLighting and mirrors are your friends when it comes to making a smaller room feel bigger. Change large floor lamps for smaller wall lights and when it comes to wall colour, stick to pale colours and swap out heavy curtains with blinds. Luckily, a big tub of value white paint goes a long way. Let in as much light as possible, give the windows a good scrub and update yellowing lightbulbs to bright white.OutdoorsIs it time to rethink that huge sofa set and professional sized goal posts  When buying furniture, think small, light and foldable so that they can be stored away in a shed or cupboard or easily moved around. Updating your garden furniture doesnrsquot need to cost the earth, yoursquoll find some really great bargain sets in supermarkets like Aldi, Asda and Tesco and homeware stores like BM.Another way to make it feel bigger is to simply give it a good tidy. Yoursquoll be surprised at how much space you do have after clearing out those unwanted flowerpots, cutting the grass and trimming back the hedges.Your home is an investment, to be enjoyed for a long time and with these simple but effective ideas, you can enjoy the space you have for longer.

title: young-people-scotland-can-get-250-free-starting-new-job
story: Young people across Scotland could be in line for as much as pound free from the Government for starting a new job, thanks to a new benefit.Its hoped the payment, which is open for applications from today, will help young people with the financial dficulties of starting a new job - including buying new clothes, travel and get childcare.It is estimated around  young people will benefit from the new financial support in its first year.What is the benefit The Job Start Payment is a one-off sum of pound for  to -year-oldsthey have been unemployed for at least six months.The upper age limit rises to  for care leavers and the payment increases to poundthe person has a child.How can I qualy for the payment To qualy for the payment, which will be delivered by Social Security Scotland, the person applying must have received a job offer for paid employment.They must be out of paid work and must have been receiving one of the qualying benefits for six months or more at the time of the job offer:Income-based Jobseekerrsquos AllowanceIncome SupportIncome-related Employment and Support AllowanceUniversal CreditWhat has the Scottish Government said Social Security Secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville said: ldquoI am delighted that our Job Start Payment is today now open for applications it really couldnrsquot come at a better time to support our young people to take up job offers.ldquoYoung people are among those whose job prospects have been hardest hit by this pandemic. As such, it is crucial that we support them and ensure they are at the heart of our economic recovery from Covid-.She added: ldquoGetting a job can represent a massive turning point for many young people, but it can also bring financial pressures.ldquoCosts like travel, new work clothes, or childcare often have to be met before people get their first pay.ldquoThe brand-new Job Start Payment will help young people with these costs, which can sometimes be a barrier to them taking up an offer, and we will be encouraging anyone eligible to apply.Full details can be found on the Scottish Government website here.

title: galashiels-golfer-wins-abu-dhabi-spot-faldo-series-final
story: A GALASHIELS golfer has won a trip to Abu Dhabi after finishing joint-second in a major competition.Jack McDonald, , played in the under- category at the Faldo Series Wales Championship last week.His performance has secured him a place in the Faldo Series grand final, which will be held later in the year at the Al Ain Equestrian, Shooting  Golf Club in the United Arab Emirates.Jack told the Border : ldquoI didnrsquot play my best golf over the three days, but given this was only my second tournament back, I was very happy with how I managed to score.A total of  girls and boys competed in the Welsh tournament, played over three rounds from August -.The first and third rounds were played on the Wales National Course at the Vale Resort, with the second at Cottrell Park Golf Resortrsquos Mackintosh Course.Jack, a plus-one handicapper at Dunbar Golf Club, carded scores of +, - and - to finish one stroke behind the winner in the under- category. He finished fth overall, once the under- playersrsquo scores had been taken into account.ldquoTo go bogey-free in the final round on the Wales National Course was hard-going in the high temperatures, Jack told the Border .He now looks forward to playing in the Middle East.Jack is supported by the Rowan Boland Trust, the George Crawford Legacy Trust, ClubSport Ettrick  Lauderdale, and Titleist Footjoy UK.

title: say-future-sqa-exams-results-fiasco
story: Pupils and parents across Scotland can have their say on the future of SQA exams following the recent results fiasco.Last week the Scottish Government made a U-turn due to anger over nearly , results being downgraded from teacher estimates by the SQArsquos controversial moderation system.Those results were later withdrawn, reverting to the original teacher estimates following an outcry from pupils and the threat of a no-confidence vote in Education Secretary John Swinney.Consultation on arrangements for National Courses in - session ndash joint statement from Scottish Government and SQA https:t.co vJgDYfSHCmdash SQAAugust , The SQA website states that ldquoplanning for the  examination diet is underway and will continue -it is important that the education system has plans in place to ensure we can cope with any disruptions.The website adds that there needs to be ldquoappropriate balance between learning, teaching and assessment in the courses.Following on fromMr Swinneyrsquos statement, the SQA launched two consultations to gather feedback on modications to qualications and adjustments to the  exam timetable.How can I have my say There are two dferent consultations being run by the SQA.A technical consultationand surveyare available on the proposed modications for each course.What is the current  timetable The planned  exam timetable will start on April ,  and finish on June , .What hasthe Scottish Government said John Swinney said: ldquoCoronavirus has had, and will likely continue to have, an impact on learning, teaching and assessment over the coming year.ldquoI am aware that many teachers will be keen to understand fully the arrangements for the assessment of national qualications in .ldquoThe Education Recovery Group has discussed a number of options in relation to this, and I welcome this consultation exercise by the SQA examining options for possible course modications that could help to support the delivery of learning, whilst maintaining the validity, credibility and standard of qualications.Full details can be found on the SQA website here.

title: scotlands-latest-coronavirus-clusters-listed-full---
story: A NUMBER of coronavirus clusters have been identied across Scotland.A chicken factory, a fishing vessel and a number of schools have been impacted as a result of the new cases.Commenting on the news, Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: ldquoWhere clusters of cases develop we must find them and act quickly to prevent further spread.But where are the clusters Here, we outline each area and their cases: Perth and Kinross:In Perthshire, the  Sisters food processing plant in Coupar Angus has been closed after four members of staff tested positive for the virus, with a further three workers awaiting results.In addition, there are two connected cases in the community.NHS Tayside said arrangements are being made for testing of employees.Close contacts are being advised to self-isolate and other identied contacts are being followed up and given appropriate advice.There has been an outbreak at the  Sisters factoryAn incident management team is working with the Scottish Government, Public Health Scotland and local environmental health teams to provide advice and support.Meanwhile two cases have been detected in pupils in the area ndash however authorities say there is no evidence of a link to the Coupar Angus cluster.One pupil attends Newhill Primary School in Blairgowrie while the other attends Oakbank Primary School in Perth, and both are currently self-isolating at home with mild symptoms along with their immediate family members.Glasgow:Health officials are also investigating a number of clusters in the central belt.Several coronavirus cases have been identied by pupils in Bannerman High School in the north-east of Glasgow ndash with the latest case involving a pupil who had attended classes.In a letter to parents, carers and pupils, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said while none of the cases had been present at the school during the period in which they may be infectious to others up until now, the new case was there during this infectious period.Bannerman High SchoolThe health board said it has undertaken a risk assessment to identy any other pupils and staff this inidual had contact with during this time.These iniduals are being contacted by the Test and Protect team and told to self-isolate.A Glasgow City Council spokeswoman said: ldquoPublic Healthrsquos assessment is that the infection is unlikely to have occurred within the school and is linked to the Baillieston virus cluster.ldquoClose contacts have been notied via test and protect and will be self-isolating for the required number of days and a letter issued on Sunday night to all families, pupils and staff with updated information.PaisleyRenfrewshire Council said on Monday that a case has been confirmed at Todholm Primary School in Paisley.,params: .pushNHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said a problem assessment grouphas systematically established a list of close contacts within the school.Test and Protect staff are now contacting those identied, who are being advised to self-isolate and being given appropriate advice and support.Todholm Primary SchoolRenfrewshire Council said: ldquoWe are following the advice of NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, who have undertaken a careful risk assessment.ldquoThey are advising there is no current evidence the virus has been transmitted inside the school and that it remains safe for pupils and staff to attend.ldquoThe Test and Protect team are currently contacting any iniduals who have been in close contact with the pupil and advising them to self-isolate at home.ldquoThe health of our pupils and staff is our biggest priority and we will continue to follow the advice of our health service colleagues over how best to protect that.Lanarkshire:Meanwhile, NHS Lanarkshire is carrying out an investigation after three pupils from St Ambrose High School and one from St Andrewrsquos High School, both in Coatbridge, tested positive.A fth case, who is linked to these but is not a pupil, has also been identied.Orkney:In Orkney, the health board said nine positive Covid- cases are now linked to the fishing vessel cluster in Orkney ndash up three from Friday.The new cases are all crew members from the boat and all have been self-isolating.AberdeenIn Aberdeen,  cases have now been confirmed in the city linked to an outbreak discovered in bars and restaurants, while , contacts have been identied.A weekly review is due on Wednesday, two weeks to the day since pubs and restaurants were ordered to close, Aberdonians were told not to visit each otherrsquos houses and restrictions were put on hospital and care home visits as a result of the localised outbreak.The First Minister told herbriefing yesterday: ldquoI think we do see signs, and itrsquos too early to be absolutely definitive about this, the increase in cases in that cluster has decelerated a bit, so it is slowing down.ldquoWe need more time to see whether itrsquos starting to properly reduce in the way we would want it to and I do think the evidence that we have thus far is that Test and Protect has done a very good job.

title: lochcarron-scotland-plans-14-selkirk-redundancies
story: UP to  more workers in the Borders face losing their jobs after a textiles company announced looming redundancies.Lochcarron of Scotland todayunveiled plans to cut jobs at its Waverley Mill site in Selkirk, pointing to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.Lochcarronrsquos managing director Dawn Robson-Bell said: "It is with much regret that we have had to make the hard decision to review staffing levels in Selkirk and the outcome will result in the region of  redundancies across a number of areas of the company."The mill and visitor centre are key tourist attractions in the town, but during lockdown they have operated with fewer reduced staff as orders and visitors have slumped.The company says the "almost complete loss" of the tourist trade in Scotland is one of the reasons for the redundancies.Ms Robson-Bell said: "The dramatic and continued effect of the pandemic on many of our markets both home and abroad has had a major impact on our turnover and our ability to sustain the business in its current format."Over the last few months we have put in place safe working practices around COVID- so that we have been able to work with reduced staffing levels to complete valuable orders.ldquoHowever, these have not been sufficient for us to operate our production continuously or at full capacity."The almost complete loss of the Scottish tourist market this year and the likelihood it will notuntil well into  is devastating for the Scottish tourist industry."As with most years, we had geared up for the start of the season in March however, our stocks remain here in Selkirk with little or no chance of these being needed anytime this year."A source, who wished to be anonymous, told the Border that staff were advised of the redundancies at inidual meetings on August , with more meetings taking place this week.The job cutswill be made across dferent departments within the business, and are intended to help secure the future of the company.Other businesses to announce Borders redundancies in recent months include OVO Energy, which had a Selkirk site, and the Galashiels call centre operated by Sykes.Have you been affected by these planned job cuts  Contact our reporters at editorial@bordertelegraph or message our Facebook page at: www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: costa-starbucks-pret-get-coffee-50p-via-eat-help
story: As the governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme continues across the UK, a new way has been revealed to get coffeefor under pound from high street chains such as Costa, Starbucks, Caffe Neroand Pret A Manger.How was the trick discovered The trick was pointed out by Rhiannon Moorhouse of Money Saving Expert, and capitalises on a couple of August schemes along with ongoing discounts.They are:The governments Eat Out to Help Out scheme will give you  per cent off you sit in a cafe or restaurant from Monday to Wednesday throughout August. You dont need a voucher as the discount will be automatically taken off your bill at the end.A recent VAT reduction from  per cent to five per cent in the hospitality sector means that a . per cent discount may be available in some places - though its up to inidual businesses as to how they do this.Many coffee shops offer discounts for bringing your own reusable cup - up to p off in some.These discounts mean that, at certain chain coffee shops, you can currently bag a coffee for around pound - or even less. Youll have to grab one before August to make the most of the available deals this months.Bear in mind, however, that prices can y slightly between branches, so the prices given below may not be exact.To claim an Eat Out to Help Out discount youll have to sit in, so the discount wont applyyoure buying from a branch without a seating area. The discount is only in place from Mondays to Wednesdays.Pret - p coffeeUsually, a filter coffee at Pret costs p. However, with a VAT discount of p, a reusable cup discount of p and an p Eat Out to Help Out discount, you should be able to grab a filter coffee for just p.With the same discounts applied to a latte - usually costing pound. - your coffee should cost just p.Costa Coffee - p coffeeCosta coffee has also confirmed that it will be passing on VAT discount to customers, and the chain business also offers discounts for reusable cups.Using these two discounts, plus the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, a small filter coffee - usually pound - should only cost around p.Flat whites, usually costing pound., will be reduced to just pound..Starbucks ndash p coffeeThe same discounts used at Starbucks will see your morning caffeine fix reduced to a similarly low price.The VAT discount wont apply to a small filter coffee at Starbucks, but with a reusable cup discount and the Eat Out to Help Out scheme discount, it should set you back just p.A cappuccino or latte - usually costing pound. - will cost around pound. with the VAT, reusable cup and Eat Out to Help Out discounts applied.Caffe Nero - pound. coffeeAt Caffe Nero, only the Eat Out to Help Out discount applies - bringing in a reusable cup will earn you an extra loyalty card stamp, however.A Caffe Latte, usually costing pound., will set you back just pound. with an Eat Out to Help Out discount.If youre an O customer, you can get a free hot or cold drink here on Tuesdays and Wednesdays with the O Priority App.Greggs ndash pound. coffeeGreggs isnt taking part in the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, but with the other two discounts, you can nab a white coffee for around pound. or a tea for p.

title: lochcarron-borders-politicians-react-selkirk-job-losses
story: BORDERS politicians have extended their support to staff who are set to lose their jobsat a local textile mill.Up to  workers at Lochcarron of Scotlandrsquos Selkirk site, at Waverley Mill, will be made redundant after a season of poor sales and low visitor numbers.John Lamont MP, who represents Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk for the Conservative Party, said: "This is more extremely challenging news for Selkirk and the textiles industry in the Borders."The Borders MP added that although businesses reliant on tourism may have a "tough time ahead", he strongly believes the textiles industry will be able to weather the storm.He said: "The Borders textile industry is world renowned and I am confident that it will be resilient enough to weather this coronavirus storm."However, it needs all the help it can get, and this includes the USA dropping their damaging export taxes on cashmere products as part of their trade war with the EU."There has been a number of job losses in Selkirk over recent weeks which has been very disappointing.:Company wants to hire  people in Borders town"However, with the local council and the South of Scotland Enterprise Agency working with both of Scotlandrsquos governments, I am confident we will be able to attract new job opportunities to the town."Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale MSP Christine Grahamealso shared her disappointment at the further redundancies in the town.Ms Grahame, whose constituency neighbours Selkirk, said: "The announcement of proposed redundancies at Lochcarron of Scotland is very unwelcome news, coming on top of previous jobs blows for the area."My concern and thoughts are with all of those who find themselves facing an uncertain future through no fault of their own."This dreadful pandemic is having a devastating economic effect all across Scotland and this area is not immune to these extremely harsh realities."However, it has not been all doom and gloom. The Peoples Energy company recently announced they will create  new jobs in the former OVO Energy premises in Selkirk. That demonstrates the Borders can compete for investment."And that recent good news should serve as a spur for everyone to redouble our efforts to attract quality jobs to Selkirk and the Borders that will safeguard employment prospects."Meanwhile, Rachael Hamilton, the MSP for Ettrick, Roxbugh and Berwickshire, said: "It is worrying to learn of more redundancies in the Borders, especially in Selkirk which has seen multiple waves of job losses since the pandemic started.ldquoLochcarron is an integral part of the Bordersrsquo textile history and it is concerning to hear of this development.ldquoI am concerned for the staff who are experiencing this dficult time and I want to offer support wherever I can."The Conservative politician added: ldquoI will be liaising with SOSEA to establish what action can be taken to ensure that people find new employment or retrain.ldquoGoing forward we need the SNP Government to take seriously the immense challenges facing the Borders at this very dficult time.

title: scotlands-rail-fares-set-price-hike----much
story: RAIL commuters across Scotland are to face a hike in season ticket prices, it has been announced.Those travelling on the railway could be faced with a .% increase in season tickets from as early as January ndash however it is understood ministers are considering delaying the  rise due to low passenger numbers as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.The Scottish Government, as well as their UK and Welsh counterparts, regulate rises for around half of fares, including season tickets on most commuter routes, some off-peaktickets on long-distance journeys, and tickets for travel around major cities at any time.Despite the rise, Transport Scotland bosses say ScotRail fares are on average % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.Examples of potential season ticket prices next year after a .% rise include:Edinburgh to Glasgow: Increase of pound to pound,Glasgow to Ayr: Increase of pound to poundKirkcaldy to Edinburgh: Increase of pound to poundA Transport Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring that rail fares are affordable for passengers and taxpayers across Scotland.ldquoWe have taken action to keep fares down and ScotRail fare are still on average, % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.ldquoWe are currently in the process of considering the options regarding future fares and tickets in relation to todayrsquos announcement on the July RPI figure as part of the wider rail recovery work post the Covid- pandemic.UK Government Department for Transport figures show car use has nearly ed to pre-pandemic levels, but rail travel is below a third of what it was before the crisis despite lockdown restrictions easing.All revenue and cost risks from train companies were transferred to the UK, Scottish and Welsh governments in March to avoid franchises collapsing.This has already cost taxpayers at least pound. billion.

title: purves-puppets-launch-fundraiser-help-biggar-theatre
story: A PAIR of puppeteers in their s are seeking donations to keep their award-winning theatre alive through lockdown.Jill Purves and her husband Ian set up Purves Puppets, in Biggar, in .Plans to celebrate the companyrsquos th anniversary were ruined by the coronavirus pandemic ndash and now the business has launched a fundraiser."Its been a big struggle," said Mrs Purves, , adding: "I would hate to give up our le.Mr and Mrs Purves, along with their daughter Vickie, run the company and the Biggar Puppet Theatre at Dene Park.The company has made numerous TV appearances over the years and appeared in shows across the world.But due to lockdown restrictions, the theatre has been closed for months.The Purves family are currently waiting to find outthey can benefit from the Performing Arts Venues Relief Fund created by Scottish Government.And despite receiving the pound, small business relief grant from Scottish Borders Councilat the beginning of the lockdown, Purves Puppets has now been forced to turn to fundraising.The owners have covered costs themselves since the grant was used up.Mrs Purves said: "Ian and I dont get wages ndash weve been living off our savings."A lot of businesses are in the same boat."We cant get a tax rebate as we dont run as profit."Customers keep phoning up ndash they want to come but they cant."We dont knowschools will be able to come out this year either."To make up for being unable to put on physical shows, the theatre has two pre-filmed productions available on its website ndash Cinderella, and Pips and Panda at the Mermaidrsquos Pool.Mrs Purves and her family have set themselves a fundraising targetof pound, to help them stay afloat, especiallythey are unable to open again before Christmas."I would hate to give up our le," said Mrs Purves. ldquoYou enjoy the pleasure of meeting families and their children."

title: coronavirus-scotland-face-coverings-become-law-schools-workplaces
story: FACE coverings could become mandatory by law in workplaces and schools across Scotland, with the First Minister not ruling out the idea.Nicola Sturgeon told her coronavirus briefing yesterday that it was ldquounder review, as the Scottish Government attempts to strike the right balance between ldquobeing as normal as possible and the learning experience for young people.It comes after a number of confirmed COVID- cases were reported in pupils across the country ndash with classes and even whole schools having to self-isolate.Face coverings could become mandatory in secondary schoolsA public health expert has since said that the mandatory wearing of masks in workplaces and secondary schools should be considered to keep them open.Coverings are compulsory in many indoor settings including shops, on public transport and in places such as cinemas, galleries, museums, libraries and banks.Professor Linda Bauld said they could be considered in other settingslevels of coronavirus go up.What did she say Asked in an interview on BBC Radio Scotland whether introducing face coverings in workplaces should be considered to allow more people to get back to work, she said: ldquoI donrsquot think we should rule it out."I thinkcases go up and we need particular settings to reopen that canrsquot, for whatever reason, face coverings indoors absolutely, but at the moment those sectors that can work from home ndash thatrsquos the message that I agree with ndash should continue to do that.Prof Bauld, who is professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, said the virus is at a ldquovery low level in terms of where we are in Scotland and that while it is circulating it is localised in terms of the rise in cases.Face coverings are already mandatory in some situationsShe said the best way to protect schools is to keep virus levels low, but that face coverings could be considered for secondary school pupils to avoid having to pause education.Prof Bauld said: ldquoIn terms of the cases that wersquore hearing about in school pupils, these are not cases that are occurring because pupils are catching the virus in the school setting, they are cases that are arising in the community, and when we have the virus circulating in the community even at low levels we know that children and young people may get it and then thereforethey go into the school they are still carrying it.She added: ldquoI thinkwe wanted to talk about, for example, face coverings for secondary school pupils rather than closing a school, thatrsquos another step we might want to discuss, thatrsquos being discussed in other places, but we donrsquot need it at the moment."We just have to think about what are the alternatives to having to pause education again because wersquore all trying to avoid that.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in more indoor public places in Scotland.This video explains where you must wear one #Detailed guidance # https:t.co QmCaYPogpic YWJXeeHmdash Scottish GovernmentAugust , ,params: .pushWhat did the First Minister say During her daily briefing yesterday, the First Minister addressed the concerns over cases in pupils ndash as well as responding to images of crowded hallways and playgrounds.Ms Sturgeon said the introduction of face masks in schools would not be ruled out.She said: "When we see anything like that, directors of education in relevant councils will be contacted to make sure they are applying all of the right guidance."We will keep all of this under review, and that includes face coverings, so that we are striking the right balance between as normal as possible in what is still an abnormal situation and learning experience for young people, but with the right mitigations in place."
