Schools are not unsafe places.”The news came in the latest Department of Health dashboard - which also revealed that now , people have tested positive in Northern Ireland.In the last seven days  people have tested positive in Northern Ireland.There are no further deaths leaving the toll at .Most of the  confirmed coronavirus cases recorded in the past  hours by the Department of Health have been aged between -.Twenty-five of the  cases recorded were in that age range.The fewest cases recorded in the department’s latest update were between the ages  - and -.The latest dashboard reveals that the majority of the  cases of coronavirus confirmed within the last  hours were recorded in the Mid and East Antrim and Belfast council areas - both with .The remainder of cases confirmed in the Department of Health’s were located in:Antrim and Newtownabbey - Lisburn and Castlereagh- Newry Mourne and Down - Armagh Banbridge and Craigavon- Causeway Coast and Glens - Derry and Strabane - Mid-Ulster - The biggest increase in cases over a seven-day-period has occurred in Mid and East Antrim with  new cases.The dashboard also reveals there are active Covid- outbreaks in eight Northern Ireland care homes.That is an increase of seven from yesterday.An active outbreak is declared in a care home when a resident or staff member has a laboratory-confirmed diagnosis of Covid-.The news comes as it emerges a meat processing plant near Ballymena is to close temporarily due to a Covid cluster.Cranswick in Cullybackey, which processes pigs, will shut at the weekend, the BBC have reported.A cluster is defined as  or more cases. No confirmation of the exact number at Cranswick.Meanwhile it also emerged that Thompsons Garage was closing in Belfast after a staff member tested positive.The statement posted on Facebook says: “Customer Announcement :: Covid- StatementUnfortunately Thompsons will be closed tonight as one of our staff members has tested positive for Covid . We will be in touch with anyone who has booked tables for tonight and issue refunds immediately.All our remaining staff members have been tested and are now awaiting their results. These results should be in today or tomorrow at the latest but sadly we cannot open until we are certain that everyone employed at Thompsons is in the clear.In the interim the entire venue is undergoing a deep clean, fumigation and decontamination in preparation for re-opening this weekend.. Our team will be in contact with everyone who has made bookings for tonight and this weekend.We’ll keep you posted on any developments! #staysafe”.Earlier today it emerged that a popular Co Londonderry bar - Dormans in Magherafelt - was closing temporarily after a number of customers tested positive for COVID-.In a statement on their Facebook page Dormans Bar said: “Since reopening our premises after lockdown we introduced in line with government guidelines stringent safety measures to ensure the protection of both our staff and customers. “We are totally committed to these measures which are constantly under review and improvement.“We however, despite the stringent safety measures we have in place, regret to inform you that three customers who visited our premises over the weekend of - August, have tested positive for Covid . “This information was supplied to us through NI Public Health Department’s Track and Trace System.“According to government guidelines we can reopen after a deep clean as it’s an isolated case but to ensure the protection of the health, welfare and safety of our staff and customers we have decided to close the premises this weekend and until all our staff have been tested, their results checked and the premises have undergone a thorough professional deep clean.“We are absolutely devastated that this has happened but unfortunately it is a situation that is unavoidable and which a lot of businesses will face in the coming months.“Thank you to all our customers for your support and our sincerest apologies for any inconveniences caused by our temporary closure.“Dormans Bar “Meanwhile, it has also emerged that two members of staff at the Galgorm Spa and Golf Resort near Ballymena have tested positive for COVID-.In a statement they said: “Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort confirmed today that it has increased safety measures for guests and team members amid concerns over an increase of Covid- cases in a number of areas across Northern Ireland, including Mid  East Antrim.It has also confirmed that following its own robust testing procedures, two asymptomatic team members who tested positive for Covid- on Thursday have been self-isolating at home, in line with company policy. The employees affected were back-of-house and had no contact with guests. The Resort’s senior team remains in regular communication with those impacted to provide support and a further test will be carried out with both team members prior to ato work.Galgorm Collection Managing Director, Colin Johnston, said:“We share the concerns around the recent increase in the number of Covid- cases and, like many employers in the area, we have been monitoring this extremely closely. In response, we have already put additional measures in place.Last week, we moved to the next phase of our agreed, comprehensive Hygiene Commitment plan which includes increased random testing of team members, who continue to operate within team bubbles.In addition, we are also the first company in Northern Ireland to introduce a Mistpal Cleansing Tunnel for team members and guests entering the Resort for further safety reassurance. This is in addition to already established measures including a nightly, full deep-clean of all areas with hospital-grade sanitiser protectant and decontamination equipment, thermal temperature monitoring, provision of hand sanitisers in all areas and adherence to recommended social distancing guidelines.The health and safety of our team and guests remains paramount and we are grateful for their continued support and also to those guests who have rescheduled their stay as a result of the robust pre-entry testing measures we have in place.”Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort has already carried out tests with almost  team members and will continue to conduct random testing and adopt the same stringent protocols already in place in the event that any further positive cases are identied.Since reopening Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort has been focused on safety as a priority and was among the first hotels in the UK to receive the AA COVID Confident Mark for its industry leading health and safety standards. UK-wide day of action highlighting the urgent government help the sector needs during the covid- crisis.The live events industry across the UK will come together, at pm on Tuesday, August  to host a series of creative action to help save the live events and entertainment sector which is on the verge of collapsing without financial support from the government.Hundreds of venues are expected to turn their lights red in more than  cities across the UK to symbolise the industry going into Red Alert.In Wales, in excess of  venues and events businesses have signed up to turn red to stress the need for support.MORE STORIESWelsh Government aims to secure the future of Wales culture sectorWales Millennium Centre in Cardf Bay will close until at least January The show must go on - says owner of Waless smallest theatre, The Small Space, BarryA large collective from the industry made up of trade bodies, businesses, freelancers and venue staff, currently on furlough, will gather in groups of no more than in front of each venue to support the #WeMakeEvents #LightItInRed campaign.Wales-based events companies will light up their trucks as they lay empty on forecourts.Welsh venues confirmed to turning red are the Motorpoint Arena, Cardf Castle, Principality Stadium, City Hall, Wales Millennium Centre, New Theatre, Chapter, St Davidrsquos Hall, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, ICC Wales.Sarah Hemsley-Cole, director of SC Productions Ltd, an events production company based in Cardf said: ldquoCovid- has had a devastating effect on the live events and arts sector here in Wales, not only our theatres, but our touring shows, stadium shows, live music venues and outdoor arts have been decimated by the pandemic.ldquoThe ecosystem of our creative industry ndash skilled professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.       ,params: .pushldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be Centre, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, and the ICC Wales.Hundreds of venues were expected to turn their lights red in more than  cities across the UK to symbolise the industry professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe girls, who are students at Cardf Sixth Form College and before that went to Stanwell School, have however chosen very dferent courses to study.Arianne who gained A* in French, A* in Politics, A* in History and A* in Biology is off to study Law with French Law at Mansfield College and Enyala who gained A* in Maths, A* in Physics, A* in Chemistry and A* in History has a place to study Materials Science at Queenrsquos College.As well as top academic students, Arianne has been part of the Welsh Debating Team and travelled to India and Thailand last year to represent Wales in the World Schools Debating Championships.Enyala won a Gold Crest Award in the Engineering Education Scheme Wales, played the leading role of Kenickie in the school production of Grease and is a keen pianist.Both girls are also members of Welsh National Youth Opera.After collecting her grades this morning, Arianne said: ldquoIrsquom so happy. I am so interested in how the legal world is changing and in particular looking at which laws we maintain and which we change coming out of the EU.ldquoCoupling law with French means that I can look at the international side of law and I am very much looking forward to learning more about both the British and French legal systems.ldquoIt is also very attractive to me to think about what the law should be from a moral perspective rather than just its application.Enyala by contrast was less sure of the direction she was going to take until she attended an Oxbridge conference in Swansea.ldquoThis was the first time I was introduced to material science she said. ldquoI really liked the structure of Oxfordrsquos course and the mixture of physics, chemistry and maths in the subject ndash it is very broad and follows on well from my EQP in nuclear energy.Both girls joined top school Cardf Sixth Form College on a  per cent scholarship from their local state school where they achieved  A*s each at GCSE.ldquoChanging schools has been a really good preparation for university le, Enyala said.ldquoIt has certainly made me more independent and aware of the world. When I joined Cardf Sixth Form I signed up for everything and particularly enjoyed playing music with some exceptionally talented musicians, taking part in badminton tournaments and performing in the drama productions.ldquoFor the first time Arianne and I have made separate friends, perhaps because we chose such dferent subjects.ldquoAs twins this is quite unusual as we are very alike in many ways but also have very dferent sides to our personalities.Arianne added: ldquoThe people were the best part of my school experience and everyone was really willing to learn and it was very easy to make friends. I felt welcome very quickly and the teachers were really inspiring. We are used to answering to each otherrsquos names so it was refreshing to actually have our own space and to realise that as well as being similar we also had room to develop very dferent talents.       ,params: .pushThe girls have also been busy during lockdown where they recorded a song and have learnt how to cook in readiness for university. Enyala has been teaching herself the guitar and Arianne has started to learn Spanish.Principal of Cardf Sixth Form College, Gareth Collier said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted that Enyala and Arianne have achieved places at Oxford as they will add so much to the community.ldquoBoth the girls have really inputted into le here at Cardf Sixth Form College with Arianne developing her leadership skills as a prefect and Enyala bringing a real sense of humour into her science lessons.ldquoI am very much looking forward to seeing how they develop and will certainly be inviting them back to share their experiences, which no doubt will be very dferent, with future students at the school. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. people indoorssocial distancing can be maintained.However, the Welsh Government will not be making any changes to the rules on people meeting indoors with people who arenrsquot part of their household Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will Butlins Nellrsquos Point site, parking capacity would be reduced.Baruc ward councillor, Steffan Wiliam first suggested the idea in response to parking concerns.He said the Island needs to be lsquofuture-proofedrsquo to cater for increased tourist numbers and ensure minimal disruption for Island residents.MORE STORIESBarry Island residents want to reclaim streets from motorists avoiding cafeacute owner, Dave Lewis said: ldquoBarry Island has a car parking problem because over the years the number of spaces have diminished and ndash with the councilrsquos plan to sell land where the Nellrsquos Point car park at the moment ndash the situation will only get worse.ldquoThatrsquos a great pity because Barry Island is such a fantastic location and - whilst there is a railway and buses ndash people come from further afield and do need parking.ldquoAt the moment we have visitors who overflow into the rest of the Island into the residential areas.ldquoAs well as being a cafeacute owner Irsquom a resident and I can see the problems.ldquoSomething needs to happen at some point to allow Barry Island to continue to grow.ldquoThe proposal for a multi-storey car park is a really good idea.ldquoWhatever is proposed and built is something that fits around Barry Island.ldquoWe donrsquot want an eyesore ndash the first thing that people see is some ugly monstrosity of a car park.ldquoIt would be really goodthere was some sort of multi-purpose construction.ldquoWhatever goes there needs to have some sort of validity as a building as well as a car park.ldquoWhatever is developed needs to provide good value, structured car parking prices.ldquoMost traders on Barry Island would say what wersquove got on Barry Island doesnrsquot really work.ldquoA pound for an hour and pound for the whole of the day and nothing in between.ldquoThis has been raised a number of times with the council, but it falls on deaf ears.ldquoThey are quite happy for visitors to be paying pound, but you canrsquot always walk from the car park for a coffee within an hour.ldquoThis is why car parking is a problem ndash because the charges are unfair.ldquoSomething needs to be done.Marco it to make it look like a ship or a sail or something like that which would blend in with the seaside.ldquoDress it so it doesnrsquot look like an eyesore from outside the Island as well ndash it could be something special there, iconic.ldquoYou could do wonderful things with some good imagination.ldquoThe Nellrsquos Point car park is still up for development andwe lose that yoursquove lost over  car parking spaces.ldquoWe need an extra  never mind .ldquoIf you multi-storey the Harbour Road one there would be a vast improvement and you would have control over it to stop the boy racers at night.ldquoAnd it would make money for the Valethey had , spaces.He added: ldquoIf residents think theyrsquove got it bad now, the residents of the West End of Barry will have it as well.Vale town and opportunities.The Optimised Retrofit Programme , part of the Innovative Housing Programme, will fund the fitting of energy efficiency measures in up to  existing homes owned by registered social landlords and councils.The investment package will lead to better homes, help tackle fuel poverty and contribute to decarbonisation.MORE STORIESWelsh ministers unveil multi-million pound support packages for local authoritiesWelsh Government unveils support package to keep people in their homes and end homelessnessExtra pound.m funding to boost household finances and manage problem debt in WalesMinister for housing and local government, Julie James launched the Optimised Retrofit Programme during a visit to Craig Cefn Parc in Swansea.The ORP will support the sector to test dferent approaches to reach the goal of carbon neutrality.It will include an innovation competition - opening next month - to support the piloting of innovative new solutions for retrofitting housing stock.The knowledge and learning gained will influence the future of the Welsh Housing Quality Standard so that all those living in social homes will benefit from reduced energy bills and warmer, more efficient homes.ORP is a key part of the poundm Innovative Housing Programme announced earlier this year, which focuses on building new carbon neutral homes using modern methods of construction, the scheme will contribute to plans to reduce greenhouse gases by  per cent by  with an ambition to reach net zero in future.Applications for the Innovative Housing Programmersquos fourth year are now officially open.A collaboration across Welsh Government, the programme has been part funded through the innovation and business streams.It has long been recognised that retrofitting homes will be a key tool in the green economic recovery, with the ambition the programme will create jobs, provide training and skills in both existing and new retrofit and heating technology.It is hoped technologies and skills created through the programme can be rolled out across wider private sector homes, ensuring Walesrsquo place as lsquofirst mover regionrsquo for decarbonisation of homes by reducing carbon emissions from around , social and fuel poor homes.Ms James said: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has highlighted the importance of a warm, secure and affordable home like never before."It has also shown the positive effects of reducing greenhouse gasses.ldquoHousing is responsible for  per cent of all energy consumed in Wales and  per cent of all demand side greenhouse gas emissions.While we have plans in place to ensure new homes are heated and powered only from clean energy sources, ensuring our existing housing stock is as energy efficient as possible is vital towe are to meet our ambitious target of reducing our greenhouse gas emissions by  per cent by .This scheme is essential to tackling climate change, and driving down household energy costs now and in the future.Helping people, including those on lower incomes, to reduce their fuel bills while keeping their homes warm.Economy minister, Ken Skates said: ldquoA welcome boost to the Welsh economy, retrofitting homes will provide quality jobs and training opportunities in the heart of our communities."To help drive forward innovation and build a Welsh supply chain we will be launching a competition for social landlords to apply for research and innovation funding in September.Deputy chief executive and director of policy and external affairs at Community Housing Cymru, Clarissa Corbisiero said: ldquoDespite the immediate threat of covid-, the climate emergency has not gone away, and the pandemic has only highlighted the need for more good quality, affordable homes."Housing associations in Wales are committed to playing their part in tackling these issues."We now have an opportunity to learn from the experiences of the last few months, and be ambitious in our response."This funding is a welcome first step to decarbonise , homes, build local supply chains and create jobs in our communities. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net title: outdoor events trialled wales easing lockdown
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe trials are part of further changes to coronavirus regulations announced by first minister, Mark Drakeford.Indoor visits to care homes will also be allowed from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.However, the first minister emphasised that theof pupils to schools and colleges from September  is the top priority during this  day regulation cycle.The Welsh Government recognises the value of the events sector to Wales and how cultural, sports and business events are a vital part of the visitor economy and one of the last sectors left to re-open.Initially three small events, with limits of up to  people, and subject to strict risk assessments, will be held across Wales later this month.Outdoor events are being prioritised in this review period, while the weather is mild, due to evidence of lower transmission of coronavirus outdoors.If these small events can be carried out safely, and transmission of the virus remains low, it is hoped the next stage will be increased numbers of participants, allowing a limited number of spectators to attend sporting events and potentially considering trialling small scale business events.In the coming weeks three small scale events will be trialled to inform future review processes.Outdoor events of up to  people include Theatr Clwydrsquos proposals for a number of live outdoor performances from August,  Welsh Triathlonrsquos planned lsquoReturn to Racingrsquo competition at Pembrey Country Park which will be a closed venue and without spectators and a car rally at Anglesey Circuit Trac Mon Race track.The Welsh Government continues to work closely with the UK Government to monitor the outcomes from the trials that have taken place recently.Mr Drakeford also confirmed that from Saturday, August , extended households can expand to include up to four households in an exclusive, extended arrangement.From the same day, weddings and funerals will be able to include a meal for up to  people, in suitably socially distant settings.Subject to the successful resumption of weddings and funerals, it is hoped to further increase the range of indoor ceremonies allowed in the next review period, including christenings, baptisms and bar mitzvahs.Casinos will be allowed to reopen from Saturday, August , provided they follow the guidance available to them.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWhile coronavirus remains effectively suppressed in Wales and cases continue to fall, the situation in the rest of the UK and further afield is still problematic."Coronavirus has not gone away and so, as we move out of lockdown and look to the future, it is important we do this in a careful and cautious way.ldquoWe appreciate how hard it has been for families not seeing their loved ones and the impact restrictions on visiting care homes is having on peoplersquos emotional, mental and even physical health.ldquoIn an effort to address this we have been working closely with partners and intend to allow indoor visits to care homes to recommence from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.ldquoIn addition we will trial three small scale events, in partnership with the events organisers, local authorities and other stakeholders, to seethey can be carried out in a safe way, with a view to supporting the sector and making the most of the remaining summer months where we can spend time outdoors.ldquoWe will also learn from pilots being conducted across the UK, in reopening professional sport and indoor theatre to supporters and audiences, so we base our decisions on the best possible evidence available."We will continue to talk with event organisers about the possible resumption of some other activities later in the autumn.ldquoBut, for the time being, we need to learn from how we can safely hold outdoor events while maintaining social distancing.ldquoWe will use the next three weeks to continue to engage with those remaining sectors of our economy that remain affected by coronavirus restrictions."I would like to thank the sector representatives for the way they continue to engage, coming out of lockdown will always be harder than going into it - but, together, we will do it in the safest possible way.From  September, schools and further education colleges willfrom the summer break, and will teach pupils through a iety of ways, either in the classroom or remotely.The First Minister added:ldquoTheof pupils is the most signicant important activity which will take place in Wales during the next  days and most of the headroom we have is being devoted to making this a success.ldquoIt is critical that we get children back into schools in the safest possible way. All children in Wales have had the opportunity to lsquocheck in, catch up and preparersquo before the summer holidays, and we hope this will stand them in good stead for the changes they are due to encounter in the upcoming months. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Mei Xiang will remain with her babyin a small indoor enclosure where she has built a modest nest.For about a week, the new mother will not leave the babyrsquos side even to eat or drink. The cub, who will not be named for its first hundred days in accordance with tradition, will remain in the den for its first few months of le.For now it is pink and hairless the distinctive black and white fur markings come later.Meanwhile father Tian Tian seems blissfully oblivious, rolling around his outdoor enclosure Saturday morning.Giant pandas are almost entirely solitary, and in the wild it would be normal for Tian Tian to never meet his offspring.### Keepers report that giant panda Mei Xiang and her newborn had a successful first night. Between bouts of good rest, Mei Xiang appeared to nurse her cub and was very attentive to its vocalizations. ## TUNE IN: https:t.co lBTVw. #PandaStory #PandaCubdates pic QCdIYvwmdash National ZooAugust , ldquoTherersquos no real role for the male to play in the babyrsquos care, Mr Monfort said. ldquoHersquos probably more interested in whatrsquos for breakfast this morning.Mei Xiang, was articially inseminated in the spring shortly after the entire zoo shut down on March  due to the Covid- pandemic.Normally they would have used a combination of frozen sperm and fresh semen extracted from Tian Tian. But in order to minimize the number of close-quarters medical procedures, zoo officials used only frozen semen.It was the first successful procedure of its kind in the US using only frozen sperm and Mei Xiang, at , is the oldest giant panda to successfully give birth in the United States.The oldest in the world gave birth in China at the age of .Mei Xiang has three surviving offspring, Tai Shan, Bao Bao and Bei Bei, which were transported to China aged four under an agreement with the Chinese government.With the indoor section of the panda house closed due to Covid- restrictions, the panda cam is really the only way to view the newborn.The zoo reopened on a limited basis July  with visitors needing timed passes to keep the crowds down.For now, zoo officials are directing panda-maniacs to the live cam, and are expecting unprecedented interest from a global population sheltering under pandemic restrictions and desperate for a bit of good news.ldquoSomething like this is kind of a miracle for us, Mr Monfort said. ldquoIt lts the spirits and of my team and the whole world..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title:  uThe whole world celebrates u on-camera birth of panda cub article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vj day event welcomed dup and sf
story: Tributes paid to cricket stalwart Harry McCroryMissing person - Gordie WalkerNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsVJ Day event welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August .
